stem: The nurse is reviewing the patient's clinical data from 0800 to 1100. Which finding most clearly indicates a worsening clinical status, potentially indicating rebound anaphylaxis?

options.text: Decreased wheezing noted on auscultation at 1100 compared to 0800.
Increased blood pressure from 90/60 mmHg at 0800 to 120/80 mmHg at 1100.
Increased reports of pruritus and urticaria at 1100 after initial improvement.
Decreased heart rate from 120 bpm at 0800 to 90 bpm at 1100.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content: 0800: Patient presented with acute anaphylaxis following a bee sting. Epinephrine 0.3mg IM was administered. Wheezing is present. Urticaria is noted across the trunk. 0900: Patient is responding to epinephrine. Wheezing has diminished. Urticaria is fading. 1000: Patient reports feeling better. No wheezing is auscultated. Urticaria is minimal. 1100: Patient reports increased itching. New urticaria is noted on the face and neck.

tabs.title: Orders
tabs.content:
• Epinephrine 0.3mg IM PRN for anaphylaxis, repeat q5-15 min x3
  • Diphenhydramine 50mg IV STAT
  • Albuterol 2.5mg nebulizer STAT
  • Monitor vital signs q15 minutes

rationale.correctRationale: The reappearance of pruritus and urticaria at 1100, after initial improvement, strongly suggests rebound anaphylaxis. This occurs when the effects of epinephrine wear off, and the allergic reaction returns. This is the most concerning finding and requires immediate intervention.

incorrectRationales.option_1: Decreased wheezing indicates improved respiratory function, a positive response to the initial epinephrine administration. This suggests the patient is initially improving, not worsening.
incorrectRationales.option_2: Increased blood pressure towards a normal range is a positive sign, indicating the epinephrine is counteracting the vasodilation associated with anaphylaxis. This suggests improvement, not worsening.
incorrectRationales.option_4: Decreased heart rate towards a normal range is also a positive sign, indicating the epinephrine's effects are normalizing the patient's heart rate. This is a sign of improvement, not worsening.

rationale.clinicalPearls: Rebound anaphylaxis can occur after the initial administration of epinephrine. Close monitoring for recurrence of symptoms is crucial. Patients should be educated about the possibility of rebound and instructed to seek immediate medical attention if symptoms return.
rationale.questionTrap: Many students may focus on the improved vital signs and miss the subtle but critical return of allergic symptoms. The question tests the ability to recognize the biphasic nature of anaphylaxis.
rationale.mnemonic: Epi-REBOUND: Remember to Evaluate Patient, Recognize Epinephrine's effects, Observe for Biphasic symptoms, Understand the need to Notify the provider, and Deliver ongoing monitoring.
rationale.correct: Rebound anaphylaxis is a recurrence of anaphylactic symptoms after initial improvement following treatment. The reappearance of pruritus and urticaria after initial improvement is a key indicator of this phenomenon and requires immediate intervention.
